metadata.title: Heart Failure and Exercise, Older Adults
synonyms: congestive heart failure (chf) and exercise, older adults
left ventricular (lv) dysfunction and exercise, older adults
left ventricular failure and exercise, older adults
description: Heart failure (HF) refers to the condition of impaired left and/or right ventricular pumping capacity. HF becomes more prevalent with increasing age, especially in persons with diseases that damage the myocardium, and is the leading cause of hospitalization in adults over 65 years of age(1)
Exercise intolerance due to exertional fatigue and shortness of breath reduces physical activity and health-related  quality of life (HRQoL) in older adults with HF(6)
Moderate evidence indicates that patients with chronic HF can safely undergo symptom-limited  cardiopulmonary graded exercise testing and participate in supervised aerobic exercise training(6,7)
Exercise training is associated with improved functional capacity and HRQoL in persons with HF(2,17,18)

This Clinical Review focuses on exercise-based  cardiac rehabilitation for improving aerobic endurance and strength in older persons with stable chronic HF. See Clinical Review…Heart Failure ; Item Number: T708726 for a general review of symptoms, pathophysiology, and patient management in HF ICD-10  codes or application of equipment  . Desired Outcomes/Outcome Measures
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition
presentation signs and symptoms: Stable, compensated, chronic HF –Increased fluid retention –Increased end diastolic volume (EDV) –Ventricular hypertrophy
Prescription for exercise-based  cardiac rehabilitation to improve physical functioning
Reduced ADLs and HRQoL due to poor functional capacity
Lower extremity/dependent edema Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Terminate exam and notify physician if any new severe cardiac or breathing symptoms are reported
Consult with physician regarding guidelines for restricting exercise based on BP readings for each patient
Exercise and exercise testing are contraindicated when SBP is greater than 200 mmHg and/or diastolic BP (DBP) is greater than 110 mmHg(3)

causes: common causes of hf in older ad: Coronary artery disease (CAD)(15)–Myocardial infarction (MI)–Chronic myocardial ischemia
Valvular heart disease/abnormal heart valves(15)–Aortic stenosis or insufficiency–Mitral stenosis or insufficiency–Prosthetic valve malfunction–Infective endocarditis
High cardiac output syndromes–Chronic anemia–Thiamine deficiency–Hyperthyroidism–Arteriovenous shunting
pathogenesis of exertional intolerance i: Left-ventricular  myocardial performance is usually assessed as the ejection fraction (EF), which is stroke volume (SV)divided by the EDV times 100. Impaired EF results from reduced SV with increased EDV . It is not uncommon, however,for older adults with HF-related exercise intolerance to have poor myocardial performance despite preserved EF(7)

The physiological correlate of aerobic capacity on cardiopulmonary exercise testing and single best outcome measure ofaerobic training effects is peak oxygen consumption (VO 2peak), expressed as milliliters O 2 per kilogram body weight perminute (ml/kg/min). VO 2peak is associated with aerobic endurance capacity and can be assessed using the 6-minute  walkfor distance test (6MWT)(3)

The determinants of VO 2peak are cardiac output (Q) and arterial-mixed  venous O 2 difference (A-VO 2D)–VO2peak = Q x A-VO 2D–Consequently, reduced age-related  VO 2peak in HF may be due to decreased Q and/or A-VO 2D

Decreased Q response to peak exercise in older patients with HF may result from–reduced peak heart rate (HR peak), which may occur secondary to-decreased number of sinus node pacemaker cells and sinus node dysfunction-diminished responsiveness to neurohumoral stimuli; e.g., sympathetic nerve stimulation, circulating epinephrine-leg fatigue that occurs during exercise before full cardiac response–reduced SV , which may occur secondary to-increased vascular stiffness/impedance to ventricular ejection-increased end-systolic  volume (ESV)-impaired LV diastolic relaxation and compliance-increased EDV-reduced EF-altered myocardial energy metabolism-reduced contractility

Reduced A-VO 2D in patients with HF may result from–decreased arterial O 2 content; in some cases, secondary to chronic anemia–increased mixed-venous  O2 content; i.e., reduced peripheral O 2 extraction-reduced microvascular circulation in the exercised muscles-reduced mitochondrial activity in the exercised muscles

The proposed peripheral pathophysiological mechanisms of reduced VO 2peak and exercise intolerance in HF include(7,8)–endothelial dysfunction secondary to deficient bone-marrow-derived  endothelial progenitor cells; reduced endothelialrepair–skeletal muscle wasting/sarcopenia, possibly due to adiponectin resistance to insulin–insufficient muscle perfusion secondary to decreased capillary density

Authors of a cohort study (N = 65; mean age 70 years) in the United States found that compared to healthy controls, thelower VO 2peak in patients with HF was associated with reduced type I oxidative muscle fibers and capillary-to-fiber ratio(8)
risk factors: Excess fluid intake; self-induced  or iatrogenic
Arrhythmias; especially atrial fibrillation and bradycardia due to sick sinus syndrome
Persistent high fever that impairs heart function
Hypoxemia due to chronic lung disease

Drugs/medications–Beta-adrenergic  blockers–Calcium channel blockers–Antiarrhythmic agents–NSAIDs–Glucocorticoids–Mineralocorticoids–Estrogen preparations–Certain antihypertensive medications (e.g., clonidine, minoxidil)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients should be cleared and referred for exercise-based  cardiac rehabilitation by their cardiologist
Physician-supervised  cardiopulmonary exercise testing is useful for individualizing the therapeutic exercise program
Monitor vital signs and general symptoms before, during, and after exercise
Follow specific precautions or contraindications from the physician at all times

Absolute contraindications to exercise(3) Recent significant change in the resting electrocardiogram suggesting significant ischemia, recent myocardial infarction (within 2 days), or other acute cardiac event Unstable angina Uncontrolled cardiac dysrhythmias causing symptoms of hemodynamic compromise Symptomatic severe aortic stenosis Uncontrolled symptomatic heart failure  Acute pulmonary embolus or pulmonary infarction Acute myocarditis or pericarditis Suspected or known dissecting aneurysm Acute systematic infection, accompanied by fever, body aches, or swollen lymph glands Other absolute contraindications –Signs and symptoms of congestion, unstable HF, or New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional class IV –Indicators of excessive exercise -Myocardial ischemia -Hypotension -Nonsustained or sustained ventricular tachycardia –Active inflammatory disease –Cerebrovascular or musculoskeletal disease preventing exercise testing or training –Severe obstructive lung disease leading to arterial oxygen desaturation –Thyroid dysfunction, hypo-  or hyperkalemia, or hypovolemia

Relative contraindications to exercise Left main coronary stenosis Moderate stenotic valvular heart disease Electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia) Severe arterial hypertension (i.e., systolic blood pressure (SBP) of > 200 mm Hg and/or a diastolic BP (DBP) of > 110 mm Hg) at rest Tachydysrhythmia or bradydysrhythmia Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and other forms of outflow tract obstruction Neuromotor, musculoskeletal, or rheumatoid disorders that are exacerbated by exercise High-degree  atrioventricular block Ventricular aneurysm Uncontrolled metabolic disease (e.g., diabetes, thyrotoxicosis, or myxedema) Chronic infectious disease (e.g., HIV) Mental or physical impairment leading to inability to exercise adequately Heart rate (HR) over 100 beats/min (bpm) in supine at rest Ventricular arrhythmia Class IV NYHA functional class HF; i.e., patient has discomfort with any physical activity and at rest; there are signs of cardiac insufficiency Body mass increase more than 4 pounds over course of 1 to 3 days, indicating retention of body water SBP decrease during exercise

Consult with physician regarding guidelines for restricting exercise based on BP readings for each patient
Exercise and exercise testing are contraindicated when SBP is greater than 200 mmHg and/or diastolic BP (DBP) is greater than 110 mmHg(3)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document date of HF diagnosis and NYHA functional classification (IIV).(4) Document date(s) of any cardiac events requiring hospitalization; note hospital course and any complications

course of treatment.medical management: Document any dietary prescriptions (e.g., low-sodium  diet, alcohol restriction); use of ventricular assistive device, portable oxygen; stent placement, resynchronization pacemaker implant, cardioverter/ defibrillator implant, other cardiac surgery (e.g., valve replacement, coronary artery bypass)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken and are they effective?  Medications commonly used in the treatment of HF Angiotensin-converting  enzyme (ACE) inhibitors(16) Angiotensin-II  blockers (ARBs)(16) Beta-blockers(16) Diuretics(16) Nitrates Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRA), formerly aldosterone antagonists(16) Digoxin Medications contraindicated in HF(16) Thiazolidinediones (glitazones) CCB (excluding amlodipine and felodipine) NSAIDs, COX-2  inhibitors Adding an ARB to an ACE inhibitor and an MRA Dronedarone (for control of frequency and rhythm in AF) Class I antiarrhythmic agents Combination of ivabradine, ranolazine, and nicorandil Combination of nicorandil and nitrates Moxonidin Alpha blockers Testosterone therapy was shown to provide improvements in functional capacity and quality of life in patients with HF(8)
diagnostic tests completed: Blood tests, urinalysis, and chest radiograph
ECG can be used to evaluate for heart enlargement, ischemia, tachycardia, arrhythmia, or atrial fibrillation
Echocardiogram can be used to calculate ejection fraction and detect valvular abnormalities
Pulmonary artery and capillary wedge pressures to assess for elevated pulmonary pressures
VO2peak to determine baseline aerobic capacity and appropriate exercise intensity for training
Maximal or submaximal cardiopulmonary exercise (typically on treadmill or stationary bicycle) testing to evaluate the ECG, HR, BP, pulmonary ventilation, and O 2 saturation
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased), with particular attention to physical activity factors
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., breathing discomfort, chest pressure/tightness)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale may be used to assess subjective exercise intensity
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings per night. Sleep disturbance is a common symptom in HF that may be related to anxiety, depression, and comorbidities
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Does the patient require the use of portable oxygen during physical activity because of respiratory symptoms or O 2 desaturation indicated by pulse oximetry? Document any orthopnea or sleep apnea Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __  -If Yes, describe ____________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms such as depression or sleep disturbance

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports?
social and occupational history.living environment: Document number of stairs and floors in home; with whom does patient live (e.g., caregivers, family members)? Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: BMI. Patients may be instructed to monitor their weight and body swelling daily to recognize signs of fluid retention. Rapid weight gain (> 4 pounds in 2 days) with increase in girth measurements is an early sign of edema/fluid retention
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess if equipment is needed; if patient has equipment, assess for proper fit and use
relevant tests and measures.balance: Patients with reduced mobility may have poor balance and be at increased risk for falls. Use Tinetti Scale, Functional Reach Test, or Berg Balance Scale, as indicated
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Assess using objective measures such as the Borg RPE, Sit to Stand Test, or 6MWT -Determine appropriateness of administering the 6MWT test
Monitor ECG for abnormal heart rhythm or ischemic changes, as indicated
Monitor O 2 saturation with pulse oximeter
Auscultate as indicated for pulmonary rales/crackles
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Screen for the presence of peripheral pulses (radial/dorsalis pedis)Assess for appropriate lifting technique, appropriate breathing when lifting, and compliance with any weight-bearing  restrictions. Note use of energy-conservation  techniquesAssess independence in transfers and functional mobility. Monitor and document vital signs before, during, and after ADLs. Use FIM, Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess need for assistive device. Document any shortness of breath, pallor, cyanosis, or diaphoresis during ambulation. Provide immediate rest if these should occur. Document vital signs during and immediately following ambulation. Also, document time until normal resting values are recovered. Assess gait safety using Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess gross strength in upper and lower extremities and trunk to identify weakness using resisted manual muscle testing (MMT)
observation inspection palpation includi: duration, using a scale of 1 to 4 (1 = 01/4  inch, disappears rapidly; 4 = > 1 inch, still present after 5 minutes)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Document any obvious malalignment that may interfere with good posture during exercise program
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess flexibility at all major joints to identify any limitations that may impact body mechanics during exerciseIdentify tasks patient reports are difficult; determine if decreased strength or endurance may limit ADLs
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ) to assess patient’s HRQoL –Borg RPE Scale to rate the patient’s subjective intensity of exercise –Dutch Heart Failure Knowledge Scale to assess the patient’s understanding of HF, as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Document patient’s orientation to time, place, and situation. Is patient alert or lethargic? Onset of confusion, restlessness, dizziness, or lightheadedness may be symptoms of worsening HF, requiring medical attention

contraindications precautions: Ask physician about precautions for patients with electrical implants (pacemaker, defibrillator) or LV mechanical assist devices

Ask physician about the safety of aquatic exercise training or swimming ›Diagnosis/need for exercise training:  HF/reduced aerobic capacity (i.e., VO 2peak) and endurance; reduced muscle strength; reduced physical functioning in ADLs with increased risk for falls
other: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to diagnosis of HF are mentioned below. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment and follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and orders of the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols
Confirm that the patient’s cardiologist has approved individualized exercise training and ascertain whether any specific exercise guidelines/precautions have been ordered for this patient

Typically, patients referred for exercise training will have undergone physician-supervised  cardiopulmonary exercise testing and specific training guidelines for the patient (e.g., exercise intensity) prescribed based on the results
Confer with physician for approval of exercise prescription based on Relevant tests and measures , above

Monitor patient for signs of overexertion: dyspnea that prevents completing a sentence; shortness of breath that does not get better when activity is decreased; dizziness or lightheadedness; chest pain or tightness; pain in arms, shoulders, neck, or jaw; irregular pulse; extreme fatigue; severe sweating; and nausea or vomiting. Educate the patient on ways to avoid overexertion
Absolute and relative contraindications to exercise are outlined above (see Overall Contraindications/Precautions )
contraindications precautions.general: HF/reduced aerobic capacity (i.e., VO 2peak) and endurance; reduced muscle

assessment plan of care.rule out: Confirm that physician has excludedasthma, chronic lung diseases, arrhythmia, infection, anemia, pulmonary embolismacute or chronic renal failure, liver disease, hyperproteinemia, venous insufficiency, pregnancy, endocrine disease, medications, lymphedema
prognosis: In patient with HF, exercise training may reduce hospitalizations related to HF and is associated with a small decrease in long term all-cause  mortality(2)
Following a generalized exercise program can result in improvements in ejection fraction which can improve overall quality of life(9)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Back to the physician for worsening symptoms during intervention Smoking cessation program, if applicable Nutritionist for dietary intervention Mental health professional for depression, psychological symptoms Sleep specialist, as indicated Aquatic therapist for water-based  exercise training
other considerations: Patients with heart failure can improve physical and functional capacities with resistance training exercises, but do not gain any additional benefits from ingesting branched chain amino acid supplementation(13)

Patients with chronic heart failure may benefit from exercise training combined with repeated sauna therapy in order to improve left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), Barthel Index score, ambulation capacity, and NYHA functional scores(14) –Based on an RCT in Japan involving 54 patients with chronic heart failure –Patients were randomized to either the repeated sauna therapy and exercise group or repeated sauna therapy only group –Both groups performed their intervention once a day for 5 days –Results show that both groups improved significantly in LVEF and NYHA functional scores; however, those in the combined therapy group showed significantly more improvements in the Barthel Index score and ambulation capacity
treatment summary: Physical functioning commonly declines in patients with chronic HF, probably due in part to exertional fatigue and dyspnea as well as reduced daily physical activity. A primary functional goal of exercise training is, therefore, to increase the ability for daily physical activity with reduced symptoms

Moderate evidence supports individualized aerobic exercise training for improving functional capacity in patients with HF.(7)A graded, symptom-limited  exercise test may be required to assess exertional responses and individualize the exercise prescription to avoid exercise-related  complications

Prescription of aerobic exercise –Guidelines: Specific exercise guidelines based on NYHA class that target patients with HF are lacking. Exercise standards for testing and training patients with heart conditions in general have been published by the American College of Sports Medicine(3) –Medical supervision: A physician or clinical exercise therapist should write the exercise prescription and supervise the exercise program. A medical response protocol should be developed and rehearsed to manage various problems or emergencies that may occur during the exercise session –Patient monitoring: HR, BP, and ECG monitoring during the exercise sessions may be necessary or prescribed by the referring physician on an individual patient basis –Warm-up:  A patient should be given a warm-up  of at least 15 minutes of gentle exercise, which may include light calisthenics and stretching, prior to starting exercise in the prescribed aerobic intensity zone –Patient orientation: The initial 2 weeks of the training program should be used to habituate the patient to the exercise modes at “light” or “easy” RPE intensity, with the session relatively short in duration (15 to 20 minutes) –Types of exercise: Stationary leg cycling, arm ergometry, and slow walking on a treadmill have been used successfully in research studies. Ambulatory patients with questionable gait safety assessed by DGI may require standby assistance when walking for exercise –Exercise intensity: Avoid exercise-induced  symptoms such as muscle pain or dyspnea that may limit exercise duration. The upper limit of exercise intensity during the stimulus phase of training (in the absence of untoward symptoms) is 60% to 70% of heart-rate  reserve (calculated as the resting HR + peak HR – exercise HR) determined on graded exercise testing. This intensity is commonly perceived as “somewhat hard” (13 on Borg RPE Scale of 6 to 20) –Exercise session duration: Target 40 minutes after the initial orientation period –Exercise frequency: Target 3 to 4 times per week –Exercise program duration: The duration of training can vary. In many studies the duration is approximately 12 weeks(10,11,12) –Patients with ischemic heart failure with an implantable defibrillator can benefit from a 12-week  aerobic interval program to improve quality of life and depressive symptoms(11) -Based on a study in Norway that included 31 patients with ischemic heart failure with an implantable cardioverter defibrillator -Patients exercised 3x/week for 60 minutes using a cycle ergometer or treadmill. Exercise sessions were broken down into 15-minute  warm-ups,  followed by performing 4 high-intensity  intervals (85% of max HR or a 15–17  Borg Scale), and ending with a 20-minute cool-down  and stretching –Aerobic interval training can improve diastolic function and cardiac power index in patients with heart failure with a reduced ejection fraction(12) -Based on a study of 120 patients with HF conducted in Taiwan. Patients were divided into the heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, or general healthcare groups -Patients performed aerobic interval training at 3-minute  intervals at 40% and 80% VO2peak for 30 minutes a day, 3x/ week for 12 weeks

Based on a 2018 systematic review and meta-analysis,  exercise significantly improves physical function and quality of life in patients with chronic heart failure(18) –Data from 5411 patients with chronic heart failure from 40 studies were included in the analysis. The studies all included an outpatient or community-based  structured exercise program as the sole intervention –The authors concluded that participation in exercise is more important than the type of exercise performed

Dance exercise may improve exercise tolerance in patients with HF. Authors of an RCT (N = 51 men; mean age 67.1 years) in Greece found that traditional Greek dancing (60 minutes, 3 times a week for 8 months) improved aerobic functional capacity similar to conventional exercise training compared to controls, but the dance group had greater intrinsic motivation and attendance than the formal exercise group(5) –The dancing group performed 10minutes of warming up followed by 40 minutes of basic, low-impact  steps, gradually progressing to more physically demanding dance steps –The formal exercise group performed 10 minutes of warm-up followed by 20 minutes of aerobic and/or stationary bike exercise, followed by 20 minutes of resistance training of the upper and lower extremities

Based on an RCT in Sweden, both yoga and hydrotherapy significantly improve exercise capacity and decrease anxiety in patients with heart failure(19) –Forty patients with heart failure were randomized into two groups: hydrotherapy or yoga training –Both groups performed interventions 45–60  minutes, twice a week for 12 weeks –Both yoga and hydrotherapy interventions equally affected quality of life, exercise capacity, clinical outcomes, and symptoms of anxiety and depression

Modified high-intensity  training (mHIT) can improve peak cardiac output and increase ventilation efficiency during exercise while reducing cardiac afterload for patients with heart failure(10) –Researchers in Taiwan studied 68 patients (35 in mHIT group and 33 in control group) with heart failure for 12 weeks –mHIT group performed moderate continuous training during the first 12 sessions followed by 24 HIT sessions. Intensity level was set at 40–60%  of VO 2 reserve. HIT activities consisted of a 6-minute  warm-up  at 20% VO 2 reserve followed by seven 3-minute  exercise intervals at 80% of VO2 reserve and finishing with a 5-minute cool-down  at 20% VO2 reserve. Sessions lasted a total of 50 minutes –Patients in the control group received only medical treatment throughout the study –Results at the end of the study show that those in the mHIT group had significant improvements in minute ventilation (VE/VO 2), heart rate, rate pressure product, and stroke volume compliance and elevated stroke volume and cardiac output

Resistance training without additional intervention is effective for increasing aerobic capacity, muscle strength, and quality of life in patients with heart failure(17) –Based on a meta-analysis  which included 10 studies and 240 participants ranging in age from 48 to 76 years –Training durations in the selected studies ranged from 8 to 24 weeks. Intensity of resistance training was up to 80% 1RM . maintenance or prevention: Reduce lifestyle-related  cardiac risk factors as indicated: normalize weight; decrease dietary cholesterol, saturated fat, and sodium intake; no smoking
